review.title: Real-time Top-K Predictive Query Processing over Event Streams
review.abstract: This paper addresses the problem of predicting the k events that are most likely to occur next, over historical real-time event streams. Existing approaches to causal prediction queries have a number of limitations. First, they exhaustively search over an acyclic causal network to find the most likely k effect events; however, data from real event streams frequently reflect cyclic causality. Second, they contain conservative assumptions intended to exclude all possible non-causal links in the causal network; it leads to the omission of many less-frequent but important causal links. We overcome these limitations by proposing a novel event precedence model and a run-time causal inference mechanism. The event precedence model constructs a first order absorbing Markov chain incrementally over event streams, where an edge between two events signifies a temporal precedence relationship between them, which is a necessary condition for causality. Then, the run-time causal inference mechanism learns causal relationships dynamically during query processing. This is done by removing some of the temporal precedence relationships that do not exhibit causality in the presence of other events in the event precedence model. This paper presents two query processing algorithms -- one performs exhaustive search on the model and the other performs a more efficient reduced search with early termination. Experiments using two real datasets (cascading blackouts in power systems and web page views) verify the effectiveness of the probabilistic top-k prediction queries and the efficiency of the algorithms. Specifically, the reduced search algorithm reduced runtime, relative to exhaustive search, by 25-80% (depending on the application) with only a small reduction in accuracy.

sections.heading: 3 Preliminaries
sections.text: In this section, we present the concepts that are central to the techniques described in the paper.

sections.heading: 3.1 Event Streams
sections.text: An event stream is a discrete, indefinitely long sequence of event instances. An event instance (or event) refers to a time-stamped action that can have an effect. A prototype for creating events is referred to as an event type. Each event instance is created by an event owner. An event type can have many instances, and an event owner can have many instances of any kind. Two events are related to each other if they share common attributes such as event owner, place, and time. These attributes are referred to as common relational attributes (CRAs). In Example 1 and Example 2, the CRAs are the session ID and the blackout ID, respectively. An event has the following scheme: < timestamp, type, CRA, attribute-set >. This is an event that has the timestamp on which it was created, the event type > event type of the event it belongs to, but the CRAs is the session, type, type, CRAs is the session, type, CRA, and the respective event ID, < an event ID, < an event ID, < an event, category, category, category, the event ID, <

sections.heading: 3.2 Causal Networks
sections.text: A causal network (or causal Bayesian network) is a directed acyclic graph G = (V, а) to encode causality, where V is the set of nodes (representing event types) and т is the set of edges between nodes. For each directed edge, the parent node denotes the cause and the child node the effect. The common probability distribution of a set of N event types E ≡ {E1,..., EN} in a causal network is asP (E) = N сi = 1P (Ei | Pai), where Pai is the set of parent nodes of the event type Ei. Consider the event stream of Figure 2. The causal relationships between the event types in the stream can be modelled as a causal network, as shown in Figure 3.

sections.heading: 4 Event Precedence Model
sections.text: In this section, we present the proposed incremental mechanism to model the precedent relationships between events in a network structure.

sections.heading: 4.1 Model
sections.text: To overcome the limitations of the existing causal models described in Section 1, we propose the Event Precedent Model (EPM), which presents the temporal precedent relationships in a first order that absorb the Markov chain, the so-called Event Precedent Network (EPN), through which further analyses are performed to predict the probable effect events based on the observed cause events. Note that the temporal precedent is a necessary criterion for a causal relationship. To avoid any loss of information, evidence of the precedence between all two events is preserved in the stream. EPM takes the partitioned window (collected from the event stream) as input and incrementally builds a model that reflects all precedent relationships in the input data. The actual data is discarded as soon as a new group of events arrives. Such an adaptive approach is essential for a streaming environment with continuous data.

sections.heading: 5 Top-K Predictive Query Processing
sections.text: In this section, we first describe the predictive query processing model and its runtime causality test, and then introduce the two top-k algorithms of continuous predictive query processing - the Exerstive Search (ES) algorithm and the more efficient Reduced Search Early Termination (RSET) algorithm.

sections.heading: 5.1 Predictive Query Processing Model
sections.text: The predictive query processing problem can be formulated as a search problem to find the possible effects of a given set of observed events in a causal network. However, the traditional causal network cannot be used for query processing due to the causal information loss and its lack of support for cyclic causality. To solve this problem, since we already know that every causal relationship is always a temporal precedent relationship, we propose to derive causality during query processing from the event precedent network in order to determine the possible effects. In our work, the predictive query is a continuous query, so that the ranking of results may change each time a new event is observed. The idea is to examine the event precedent network (EPN), which represents all precedent relationships (including cyclical precedent relationships) among the event types, in order to determine the predictive effects of the cause of the variable fraction effects are always available.

sections.heading: 5.2 Exhaustive Search Algorithm
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Approach
sections.text: The simplest solution to the top-k prediction problem is to search for all possible effects exhaustively during runtime causal conclusion via EPN and then sort them, according to their results, in no increasing order to determine the k effects with the top scores. We call this solution the Exhaustive Search (ES) approach.The ES approach should be a robust strategy for researching the EPN to derive effects. As discussed earlier, an outward-looking breadth initial search via the EPN for runtime causal conclusion can be executed. However, the score calculation of the effects is not straightforward. In order to apply the multiplicative property of conditional probability, which is described in Section 5.1, the results of the parents of an event type should be calculated which is not always calculated, which is not always possible, as shown in Figure 6. We define a search order, called causal search, to the exploration of the EPN, prior to exploration of the EPN.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Algorithm
sections.text: In the first run, the width-first search is performed via the EPN to determine the causal search order. In the second run, EPN is examined with this search order for the runtime-causal inference; the input to the algorithm is the size of the result, the event preference network G, and the set of recently observed cause-event types arranged in chronological order; the four main steps of the algorithm are given as follows. First, an outward-looking search via G from EOP (the latest cause-event type CB) is executed to determine the causal search order; line 1 shows this step.Second, the marginal independence tests between the event types are performed during the search to remove weak relationships (lines 2-7).

sections.heading: 5.3 Reduced Search Early Termination Algorithm
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.3.1 Approach
sections.text: The ES algorithm searches exhaustively in the EPN during query processing to determine the top k results, and therefore it can be quite slow. More importantly, it scales very poorly and therefore this approach is probably insoluble for a large network. Of course, there is a need for an alternative method that is faster. There are two problems to deal with for this purpose. Runtime: With the full search for ES on EPN to find all possible results, the search space increases with the number of variables and performs unnecessary calculations. A good quantum processing method should avoid redundant and unnecessary calculations to reduce runtime. Accuracy: Normally, the goal conflict for reducing runtime is the loss of accuracy of the results. Runtime is reduced by reducing the search space, which can skip the correct effects events. The quantum processing method should avoid such an incident as far as possible.

sections.heading: 6 Performance Evaluation
sections.text: We conduct experiments to evaluate the causal inference model at runtime and the top-k query processing mechanism in the proposed RSET algorithm and the ES algorithm. One evaluation refers to the accuracy of the top-k results, the other to runtime. Section 6.1 describes the setup of the experiment, including the evaluation metrics, data sets and platform used, and Section 6.2 presents the test results.

sections.heading: 6.1 Experiment Setup
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6.1.3 Experiment Platform
sections.text: The experiments are carried out on a 2.3 GHz Intel Core i5 computer with 4GB of memory under Windows 7, the algorithms are implemented in Java 1.7.0.

sections.heading: 6.2 Experiment Results
sections.text: We perform two sets of experiments to evaluate the RSET and ES algorithms. One set of experiments is to evaluate the accuracy of the prediction, and the other set of experiments is to evaluate the runtime. There are two goals in each set of experiments. The first goal is to compare the query processing with the causal inference mechanism of the runtime (of RSET and ES) against the query processing with the traditional causal inference mechanism (of the FCNI algorithm). For a fair comparison, since the goal is only to compare the causal inference mechanisms, the query processing mechanism can be used in either the RSET algorithm or the ES algorithm in the FCNI algorithm, and in this experiment we choose the RSET algorithm. The second goal is to compare the causal processing mechanisms of the query process between the RSET algorithm and the ES algorithm.

sections.heading: 6.2.1 Accuracy
sections.text: The aforementioned beginnings in the real world in which they are located have never been as widespread in the real world as in the real world in which they are located.

sections.heading: 6.2.2 Runtime
sections.text: In this experiment, we compare the runtime between the three algorithms (RSET, ES, FCNI). In addition, we analyze the effects of k on runtime. Figures 14 and 15 show the runtime for the MSNBC dataset and the power grid dataset. In these figures, the runtime of the three algorithms is compared for different values of the EOP index. (The results show that the runtime of the events is set in the condition.) In addition, Figure 16 shows the runtime for different values of the MSNBC and the power grid datasets. (Comparison of the causal inference mechanisms.) The results show that the runtime of the RSET and ES algorithms is longer than the runtime of the FCNI algorithm for each value.

sections.heading: 6.2.3 Discussion of experiment results
sections.text: The proposed causal inference mechanism at runtime in the RSET and ES algorithms is therefore more suitable for cyclical causality and avoids the loss of causal information, thus greatly improving the accuracy of predictions. However, the FCNI algorithm performs worse than both the RSET and ES algorithms because it cannot handle cyclicity. Intuitively, the accuracy of the FCNI algorithm would suffer increasingly as the number of cycles increases over the number of cycles in the EPN. Therefore, despite its reduced runtime, the FCNI algorithm is not suitable for processing predictive queries on event streams.The accuracy of the RSET algorithm is comparable to the accuracy of the ES dataset.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: This work focused on the problem of continuous top-k prediction of event flows. We therefore proposed a novel causal inference mechanism, called runtime causal inference (RSET), to support cyclical causal relationships and overcome causal information loss. Then, we proposed two algorithms for query processing, the so-called Reduced Search with Early Termination (RSET) algorithm and the Exhaustive Search (ES) algorithm, which uses causal inference to continuously predict top-k effects. Finally, we demonstrated through experiments that the proposed approach overcomes the two main limitations of the traditional causal inference approach - acyclic causality and causal information loss. We showed that the proposed RSET and ES algorithms predict the causal inference force for real data that nowadays in different areas of application we anticipate that there will be significant improvements to the series of future events in the timetable.There are a number of problems we anticipate in the current.

metadata.abstractText: This paper addresses the problem of predicting the k events that are most likely to occur next, over historical real-time event streams. Existing approaches to causal prediction queries have a number of limitations. First, they exhaustively search over an acyclic causal network to find the most likely k effect events; however, data from real event streams frequently reflect cyclic causality. Second, they contain conservative assumptions intended to exclude all possible non-causal links in the causal network; it leads to the omission of many less-frequent but important causal links. We overcome these limitations by proposing a novel event precedence model and a runtime causal inference mechanism. The event precedence model constructs a first order absorbing Markov chain incrementally over event streams, where an edge between two events signifies a temporal precedence relationship between them, which is a necessary condition for causality. Then, the run-time causal inference mechanism learns causal relationships dynamically during query processing. This is done by removing some of the temporal precedence relationships that do not exhibit causality in the presence of other events in the event precedence model. This paper presents two query processing algorithms – one performs exhaustive search on the model and the other performs a more efficient reduced search with early termination. Experiments using two real datasets (cascading blackouts in power systems and web page views) verify the effectiveness of the probabilistic top-k prediction queries and the efficiency of the algorithms. Specifically, the reduced search algorithm reduced runtime, relative to exhaustive search, by 25− 80% (depending on the application) with only a small reduction in accuracy.
